STP.title: Sao Tome and Principe
STP.summary: Island archipelago in the Gulf of Guinea where exiled Black Jews from Portugal were settled—connecting the Iberian expulsions to the West-African Israelite diaspora.

historical_refs.claim: E. H. Lindo (1849) records that many expelled Castilian Jews—identified as dark-skinned Israelites—were enslaved and sent by the Portuguese to populate the island of São Tomé. This event connects the Iberian expulsions to the early African dispersal of the Israelites along the West African coast.
historical_refs.source: E. H. Lindo, The History of the Jews of Spain and Portugal (London: Longman, Brown, Green & Longmans, 1849), p. 55.

NG.title: Nigeria | West Africa
NG.summary: A major Semitic nation, now referred to as West African, with historical ties to ancient migrations of ancient Israelites.

biblical_refs.note: The Lord will recover the remnant of His people from Cush and beyond, linking to regions west of the Nile where later Israelite migrations reached—now associated with Nigeria.
From beyond the rivers of Cush, the dispersed bring offerings—describing lands west of ancient Cush corresponding to the Nigerian region.
Princes shall come out of Egypt; Ethiopia shall stretch forth her hands unto God—prophetically encompassing Semitic descendants of Israel living as West Africans.

historical_refs.claim: Wilson Armistead (1848), cites reports of Niger Jews descended from Judea who settled along the coastline of Africa. These communities, distinct in custom, are described as Negro in appearance, preserving their Israelite identity — living among or within the West African homogeny.
historical_refs.source: Wilson Armistead, A Tribute for the Negro (London: William Ball, 1848), p. 66.

images.alt: Cover — A Tribute for the Negro (1848)
Page 66 excerpt noting Niger Jews descended from Judea along the African coast

historical_refs.claim: James W. C. Pennington (1841), records early descendants of the Negro race are of Semitic origin — linking them to ancient Israelites dispersed throughout Iberia. His work reflects the historical connection between Black Jews of Portugal and the Spanish Inquisition, where the Israelites were expelled due to colonization and the Trans-Atlantic Slave Trade.
historical_refs.source: James W. C. Pennington, A Text Book of the Origin and History of the Colored People (Hartford: L. Skinner, 1841), p. 96.
